author: Shoumojit Banerjee
text:
Giving a clean chit to the Dalit students in the Fergusson College row, the Pune police on Friday said there was no anti-national sloganeering during a programme organised by the right-wing Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad (ABVP) earlier this week.

“We consider the issue closed. The slogans raised by students during the event were only against alleged ‘bad governance’ and ‘persecution of minorities.’ We have studied the footage of the event carefully,” said Tushar Doshi, Deputy Commissioner of Police, Pune.

On Tuesday, an Ambedkarite group and the right-wing ABVP verbally clashed at an event addressed by ABVP’s student president in JNU, Alok Singh, forcing the college authorities to call in the police.

Principal R.G. Pardeshi thought that the Dalit students had raised anti-national slogans and sent a complaint to the Deccan Gymkhana police.

“I request you to take stern action against individuals who raised anti-national slogans on the campus,” Mr. Pardeshi had said in his letter.

On Wednesday, Mr. Pardeshi withdrew his complaint citing “typographical errors.” Many Dalit representatives staged protests against the principal.

Police say they were against ‘bad governance’ and ‘persecution of minorities’
title: ‘No anti-national slogans raised in Fergusson college’
